questions.question: You have gone to a village for screening where people have diabetes and hypertension. What type of screening is done for family members of these patients who show up in large numbers?
questions.explanation: exposure. In this case, family members of diabetic and hypertensive patients are at a higher genetic and lifestyle risk of developing these conditions. This approach optimizes resources by focusing on a subgroup with a greater probability of disease, improving early detection and intervention. Types of Screening in Public Health Screening programs are classified based on population coverage and purpose . Type of Screening Description Example Mass screening Testing entire populations , regardless of risk. Screening all adults in a village for hypertension. High-risk screening Targeting individuals with known risk factors . Screening family members of diabetics for early detection. Multiphasic screening Conducting multiple tests in one session to detect various diseases. Screening for diabetes, hypertension, and cholesterol simultaneously. Anonymous screening Testing where participants' identities remain unknown . HIV screening in high-risk populations without recording names. Multiphasic screening (Option A): Incorrect because this involves testing multiple diseases in one go , rather than focusing on a high-risk group. Mass screening (Option B): Incorrect because mass screening includes everyone , not just high-risk individuals. Anonymous screening (Option D): Incorrect because identity is not concealed in this scenario; screening is based on family history. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 26th Edition Pg: 153

questions.question: Diabetic screening for the pregnant mother in India is done between:
questions.explanation: second trimester, specifically between 24 and 28 weeks of pregnancy. This screening is important to identify gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), a type of diabetes that develops during pregnancy and can pose risks to both the mother and the baby. GDM is characterized by elevated blood sugar levels that occur during pregnancy and usually resolves after childbirth. Incorrect Options: Option B - 32-36 weeks: It is not the typical timeframe for diabetic screening in pregnancy. By this time, if GDM has not been identified earlier, it might be too late to implement effective interventions. Option C - 18-24 weeks: It is relatively early in the pregnancy and not the standard time for diabetic screening. GDM usually becomes more evident as pregnancy progresses. Option D - 14-18 weeks: It is also relatively early in the pregnancy and not the standard time for diabetic screening. GDM typically develops later in pregnancy due to changes in hormone levels and insulin resistance.

questions.question: The current approach for the initial screening of women for cervical cancer at a primary health center is-

options.A: Visual inspection after application of freshly prepared solution 5% acetic acid solution

questions.explanation: solution Correct Answer A - Visual inspection after application of freshly prepared solution 5% acetic acid solution: Visual inspection after the application of a 5% acetic acid solution, also known as VIA (Visual Inspection with Acetic Acid) is a widely used and effective method for the initial screening of cervical cancer in resource-limited settings. Visual inspection with acetic acid (VIA): is a simple and cost-effective method that involves the application of 5% acetic acid to the cervix. The acid causes any abnormal areas to turn white, which can be visually detected. VIA is a suitable screening method in primary health centers as it does not require sophisticated equipment or extensive training. If an abnormal area is detected, further diagnostic tests such as colposcopy and cervical biopsy may be recommended. Colposcopy (Option B): Is not typically used as an initial screening method in primary health centers due to the need for specialized equipment and trained personnel. Cervical biopsy (Option C): Is an invasive procedure and is not typically performed as part of the initial screening process. High vaginal biopsy (Option D: Is not a specific screening method for cervical cancer and is not commonly used as an initial screening strategy. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4478664/

questions.question: For assessing the viral load in a test sample, which test utilizes the provided graph?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B - Real-time RT PCR The above image shows the cycle threshold or Ct value of Real time RT PCR which is used to assess the viral genetic load. In the graph above, the cycle number is on the x-axis and relative fluorescence is on the y-axis. Real-Time RT PCR CT value (cyclical threshold) - Inversely Proportional to virus load. The CT or threshold cycle value is the cycle number at which the fluorescence generated within a reaction crosses the fluorescence threshold, a fluorescent signal significantly above the background fluorescence. At the threshold cycle, a detectable amount of amplicon product has been generated during the early exponential phase of the reaction. The threshold cycle is inversely proportional to the original relative expression level of the gene of interest. Antigen test (Option A): A rapid antigen test, is a rapid diagnostic test suitable for point-of-care testing that directly detects the presence or absence of an antigen. CBNAAT (Option C): The cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification test (CBNAAT) assay is a real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR) cartridge-based assay for the simultaneous detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis complex and rifampicin resistance from biological specimen samples within two hours. TruNat (Option D): TrueNat is a comprehensive test for screening and confirming the COVID-19 virus in India. Reference: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8232180/

questions.question: Which of the statements below is correct? true positive

options.A: In a population with low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test means
options.B: Sensitivity depends on prevalence of the disease
options.C: Positive predictive value depends on prevalence of disease
options.D: Specificity depends on prevalence of the disease

questions.explanation: Predictive Value (PPV): It is the probability that individuals with a positive test result truly have the disease or condition of interest. It indicates how well a test result predicts the presence of the disease. Formula: Negative Predictive Value (NPV): It is the probability that individuals with a negative test result do not have the disease, reflecting the diagnostic power of a test to exclude disease correctly. It indicates how well a negative test result predicts the absence of the disease. Formula: Incorrect Options: In a population with low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive (Option A): In low disease prevalence, a positive result with a highly sensitive test doesn't always mean a true positive. Sensitivity depends on prevalence of the disease (Option B): Sensitivity isn't influenced by disease prevalence; it measures a test's ability to identify individuals with the disease. Specificity depends on prevalence of the disease (Option D): Specificity isn't influenced by disease prevalence; it measures a test's ability to identify individuals without the disease. Reference: Monaghan TF, Rahman SN, Agudelo CW, Wein AJ, Lazar JM, Everaert K, Dmochowski RR. Foundational Statistical Principles in Medical Research

questions.question: What factor is the external validity of a screening test associated with?
questions.explanation: generalizability, which determines if the test results can be applied to a broader population beyond the study sample. Incorrect Options: Stability (Option A): Stability refers to consistency over time. Objectivity (Option B): Objectivity pertains to bias. Repeatability (Option D): Repeatability concerns consistency within individuals. Reference: Patino CM, Ferreira JC. Internal and external validity: can you apply research study results to your patients? J Bras Pneumol. 2018 May-Jun;44(3):183. doi: 10.1590/S1806-37562018000000164. PMID: 30043882; PMCID: PMC6188693. O M Dekkers and others, How to assess the external validity of therapeutic trials: a conceptual approach, International Journal of Epidemiology, Volume 39, Issue 1, February 2010, Pages 89–94

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of prospective screening?

options.A: Cervical Pap smear in a 40-year-old patient
options.B: Neonatal screening of a new-born baby for hypothyroidism
options.C: Screening of immigrants for infectious diseases such as tuberculosis
options.D: Urine for sugar screening in a 40-year-old man

questions.explanation: immigrants for diseases like tuberculosis ensures the health of both immigrant and host populations and is an example of prospective screening. Prescriptive Screening Prospective Screening Done for their own benefit. Secondary level of prevention. Early diagnosis. Done for other's benefit. The primary level of prevention. Control/ prevention of disease. E.g. Screening neonates for neonatal hypothyroidism (Option B ruled out) Deafness in children Blood glucose testing for diabetes mellitus and gestational diabetes Mammography for breast cancer Pap smear for cervical cancer (Option A ruled out) Visual acuity for refractive errors. Urine sugar screening for diabetes (Option D ruled out) E.g. Screening of immigrants for diseases like TB and COVID (Option C) HIV screening for blood donation HIV screening in ANC cases Health checkups for workers in the food industry. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition Pg: 161-162

questions.question: A healthy person got in contact with an infected case, and they have to separate him as he is sick now. This is:
questions.explanation: and potentially infectious from others to prevent disease spread, occurring either in healthcare facilities or at home based on illness severity and resource availability. Isolation Quarantine For people who are sick For well people who may have been exposed to a communicable disease Separates people who are sick from those who are not sick Applies to people who may or may not become sick Restricts movement of people with an infectious disease to stop the spread of the Illness Restricts the movement of healthy people who may develop a disease after possible exposure to an infectious agent Allows for appropriate treatment in a hospital type/setting Requires people to stay in a designated location, e.g. their home. For a specified period of time Requires appropriate personal protective equipment (ppe) for those coming into contact with the person who is sick Requires active monitoring including taking temperature twice daily and checking for other symptoms Requires proper infection control, sterilization and waste management PPE not required for contact with people who are not ill Absolute Quarantine (Option A): It separates and restricts the movement of individuals exposed to a contagious disease but not yet symptomatic to monitor for symptoms and prevent potential disease spread upon becoming infectious. Interruption of transmission (Option C): Tactics to halt disease spread, including tracing, quarantine, and hygiene. Serial interval (Option D): Time between primary and secondary case symptoms, revealing transmission patterns. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Pg 132

questions.question: Which factor has the greatest impact on positive predictive value?
questions.explanation: proportional to the prevalence of a disease it detects, i.e., PPV increases as the prevalence increases provided the sensitivity and specificity of the test remains unchanged over the course of time (since prevalence can be considered as the pre-test probability of a disease) Example: Total population of a town is 2000. Prevalence of a disease at three different time periods are 10,20 and 30% based on a definitive investigation. Sensitivity and specificity of a new test are 40% & 70% respectively Since the sensitivity & specificity are going to be considered as constants throughout, the number of true positives and hence the positive predictive values will increase proportionately to the given prevalences over these three different time periods. Sensitivity (Option A): Sensitivity impacts the true positive rate, not PPV. Specificity (Option C): Specificity affects the true negative rate, not PPV. Relative Risk (Option D): Relative risk does not affect PPV. Reference: Park’s textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page 151-153, 156

questions.question: What is the term used to describe the time interval between points A and B in the flowchart depicting the natural progression of the disease?
questions.explanation: diagnosis point (A) to the critical diagnosis point (B). Lead time: Time gained by early detection of disease or time difference between the earliest possible point of diagnosis and the usual time of diagnosis. (Option A ruled out) Generation time (Option C): It refers to the interval of time between receipt of infection by a host and maximal infectivity of that host. This option is incorrect. Lag Time (Option D): Not shown in the image; refers to symptom development to diagnosis. Hence, this is incorrect option. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine 26th Edition Pg: 107-08, 151-52

questions.question: Which of the following is the best level of prevention of breast cancer?
questions.explanation: cancer prevention. Detecting it early through methods like mammography improves outcomes. Incorrect Options: Option A - Specific Protection: Specific protection involves reducing risk factors, not early treatment. Option C - Disability limitation: Disability limitation minimizes disease impact, not prevention. Option D - Rehabilitation: Rehabilitation enhances life post-diagnosis, not prevention. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: If a patient tests positive for a disease, which of the following represents the probability of her actually having the disease?
questions.explanation: actually has the disease given a positive test result, considering sensitivity and disease prevalence. PPV = True Postives / (True Positives + False Positives) Incorrect Options: Option A - Sensitivity: Identifies true positives but doesn't assess the probability of having the disease. Option B - Specificity: Identifies true negatives but doesn't assess the probability of having the disease. Option D - Negative predictive value: Assesses the probability of not having the disease given a negative test result, not a positive one. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: In the following natural history of disease flowchart, point A to C is called as?
questions.explanation: (A) and the final critical point of diagnosis (B). It allows for early intervention and treatment, potentially improving health outcomes. Incorrect Options: Option A - Screening Time: Refers to the period of screening before symptoms appear, not related to points A and B in disease flow. Option C - Lag Time: Refers to the time between exposure to a risk factor and symptom manifestation, not specific to points A and B. Option D - Generation Time: Time for disease-causing agent reproduction, not relevant to points A and B in disease flow. Reference: 1. Notes, 2. Ref: Park’s textbook of preventive medicine, edition: 25

questions.question: In a population of 1000 individuals, a screening test was conducted for DM (diabetes mellitus). It showed that 90 individuals tested positive for DM. Subsequently, a gold standard test for DM was conducted, and it showed that 100 individuals tested positive. Your task is to determine the sensitivity of the screening test.
questions.explanation: the disease (true positives). In this case, out of 100 individuals with diabetes, the screening test correctly identified 90 (true positives). Therefore, the sensitivity of the screening test is 90/100 Incorrect Options: Option B, C and D are incorrect. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A large number of tests were done in series. Which of the following will be true?

options.B: Sensitivity will decrease, and specificity will increase
options.D: Sensitivity will increase, and specificity will decrease

questions.explanation: measure a test's performance. Sensitivity: Identifies individuals with the condition (true positives). Specificity: Identifies individuals without the condition (true negatives). Conducting multiple tests can reduce false positives, increasing specificity. Sensitivity may decrease while specificity increases with more tests in series. Incorrect Options: Option A - Sensitivity and specificity will Increase: Wrong, as test performance isn't directly tied to the number of tests. Option C - Sensitivity and specificity will decrease: Incorrect, as multiple tests don't necessarily lower sensitivity and specificity. Option D - Sensitivity will increase, and specificity will decrease: Inaccurate; sensitivity usually doesn't rise while specificity drops with more tests. Reference: Prepladder Notes
